reviews.review_msg: Professor David Newman is very smart. But, his lecture are often lengthy, boring disorganized and repetitive. I think he really needs to work on making the course more relevant and informed.

I've taken two courses with David now, and never will again. He's incredibly disorganized, to the point where half the time the materials were not on Canvas when they were supposed to be. We spent a lot of time sitting in lecture listening to him talk about Lord of the Rings, or New Zealand. Avoid him if you can, especially for lower divisions.

Donald was very into the course topics and always encouraged us to participate and discuss, he would often babble onto other relevant topics during lectures but they were pretty interesting stories! Because I took this course during summer, we were able to get real experience by going on a field trip. The material learned was very interesting.

There was quite a lot of work to do in the class, but it was NOT HARD. The midterm was the easiest test I have taken so far in my undergrad, short answer and multiple choice, just have to study the lecture slides.   Overall David made the class enjoyable. Assignments were straight forward. Take home final. And easy opportunity for extra credit.

I had David for both 230 and 235. He's incredibly disorganized. It took him weeks to get the course material up on Canvas, and he kept forgetting to submit the course pack to the bookstore so students could buy it. I would avoid taking classes with him if possible, unless you don't mind three hour lectures on his native New Zealand.

Lectures are a little long but very informative.  The subject matter is a little dry but David does make it more interesting.  Fair tests.  Really helpful if you need assistance in understanding an assignment better.  Be ready to write at least 500 words every week and complete all the readings.  I would take another class with David.

This is my second course with David Newman. After taking 130 with him, I basically felt hopeless. But I have really enjoyed 230 with him! Not only is the material more interesting, but David has a fair course structure. Would recommend.

David gives a lot of chances to earn extra credit. He's lecture could be dry sometimes, but he has a great passion on the subject and he's always helpful if you ask him for help. The TAs are helpful also. Not a tough grader in general, there's a lot of readings, make sure you do them before the lecture. Will take he's class again.

I had him for CMNS 130 and 230, He barely had a criteria for the 130 term paper, AND HE HAS NO CRITERIA AT ALL FOR 230, not for the case study paper, not for the presentations, nothing, it seems as if all the grades are given arbitrarily, if you've never written a case study, good luck. Lectures are boring, readings are irrelevant and unnecessary.

Lectures were very boring. Tutorial presentations were expected to be creative and powerpoint was not allowed, but the professor gave the same boring power point presentation over and over again. The midterm was quite difficult and material partly came from tutorial presentations (which gave students in some tutorials an advantage).
A gentle person. I really enjoyed doing the tutorial presentations, it's a great way to absorb the material.
David is the most boring and uninteresting prof I have ever had. He is very dry, and not to mention... monotone.

David is very passionate about the material. He often talks about unrelated topics about his personal career during lecture. The course content itself, was interesting but scattered. The readings are unrelated to lecture and dry, but are important for the midterm. He points out what parts of lecture will be in the tests. Lots of projects.

David. What can I say. He is a very knowledgeable guy and he really does love Peter Jackson. Class set up is not overly difficult, but material can be somewhat dry, try and make the most of it and his Lord of the Rings love.

Although David's lectures are rather boring and he manages to relate everything to Peter Jackson and Lord of the Rings, he's an excellent prof who cares about the success of the students and will go out of his way to be helpful. He's great :)

This course has potential to be incredibly interesting. The material is a bit dated and he is apprehensive to talk about social media as a cultural industry, which is disappointing. He is too disorganized and goes on unrelated tangents about himself. He has high expectations, but is not accountable himself, often giving grades back VERY late.

David was very helpful throughout the course. He is compassionate, a good listener and wants his students to succeed. He loves to tell stories which are helpful in the real life but he misses time to explain concepts. Overall. Good prof.

David made this class worth attending. He was very passionate about the content of this course, and was very knowledgable on all aspects of the cultural industries. This course is especially interesting if you're looking to one day be involved in the film industry.Class discussions were highly encouraged, and made the lectures more enjoyable.

I've taken CMNS 130 (Prof) and 230 (TA) with David and he is the best prof I have had at SFU thus far.  Not only does he help students reach their potential in the course, but teaches with a passion and enthusiasm for the course material.  David is extremely knowledgeable in the course material and is completely approachable.

One of the best TAs at SFU.  Honestly, i think David is smarter than the prof.  He is not an easier marker, but  I managed to achieve a pretty good grade in his class.  His comments written in my papers are very helpful.  Highly Recommended.
Great TA! He's helpful and approachable. If you have any questions regarding any of your assignments, he will try to answer your question and wishes you to get a good grade for the assignments.

Awesome.  Very helpful and knows his stuff. Very responsive to student questions and problems. If you are in doubt or have a problem, then ask him. Also has done 261. Take him if you have a chance. One of the best TA's you can have.
Excellent and entertaining prof. Highly recommended. My only complain is that his lectures are 8:30 in the morning-->way too early.

Wow.I am surprised I am still in her lecture right now. It is absolutely irrelevant to the course and all she does is talk talk talk. As other users have said, she is in love with her voice. She is enthusiastic about communication, but she does not make it interesting for us. Prepare to bring a pillow and a blanket if your taking anything with her

I have no idea what she's talking about! LOTS of jargon. she speaks well, but after each sentence ur thinking..."oooook so what was she saying?" excessive notes that are useless. Advice: Take CMNS 261 w/ this course, they're SO SIMILAR and it will help!

She's definitely a smart woman, but not a very professional instructor. She goes on and on talking about random things that may sound relevant to the course but in fact not. Her lecture style makes people not want to go to class and confuses students. She's not very clear abt things. Thank goodness she's pretty easy. That makes up for it.

Very intelligent, dynamic, and energetic, but doesn't seem to be cut out at teaching. Really disorganized with basic course logistics ie. making readings available, organizing assignments. Uses a lot of complicated jargon which can be confusing. Great personality but terrible teaching skills.

Neil is super nice and super smart. He's very laid back and humble. People love him. You do have to be sure not get too into his Simpson's references and loose track of what points you need to be understanding and paying attention too. Unfortunately, he has left SFU for Toronto. Booooooo. We want him back!
Scattered, difficult to take notes in class, no connection betw lecture and text
he is engaging and full of knowledge in all sorts of areas.  He cracks me up too
No Comments
No Comments

Hated her. Tutorials were utterly boring and I agree with previous comments, weird personality, lack of interest in teaching, worst TA ever. Also, is she like the only TA listed here? That's further proof of how bad she is. Dear god please never let her be a professor.
SUCH a difficult marking TA, avoid at ALL costs

Really good prof, very clear, well-organized lectures. it was very obvious that if you paid attention in class and did the readings that you would do well on the exams. Available for extra help in office hours, and gave me very good suggestions for my paper. This wasn't exactly an 'easy' course, but it had very clear expectations on how to do well.

Great class, and while there were lots of slides the information related well to the readings. If you did your readings  and attended lectures the slides were easy to understand and weren't overwhelming. Final was open book and fair-- no surprises.
She expects a lot from you, lectures are confusing and misguided, and it is hard to understand what exactly you will be graded on as there is a cumulative 1300 slides plus readings that are tested.
She gets offended if called by her first name. MUST call her DR./Professor. She needs to be praised and is often disrespectful & condescending. She is not the most encouraging professor.
Sarah's PowerPoints are hard to read and seems like she put them together 20 min before lecture. The teaching assistants are the ones you should rely on to get a good grade.

Lecture readings were dry, but the lecture and course material itself were interesting. Midterm (30% - made out of study questions, no final), self-reflection (20%), and case study (30%) were well balanced. Lecture material was also super up to date and current, which made it more interesting.

So far, great course! Very clear and structured. The study questions for the midterm were beyond helplful and assignments are very reasonable. I actually enjoy her lectures, she involves the class with questions and makes dry materials interesting and recent.

To be honest, lectures were brutally boring. The content itself is dry and the readings are longish. However, she gives study questions that entirely make up the midterm exam. Supplement your answers with reading examples and it's an easy A. Start the case study early because it's worth 50%. Not a hard class, just study properly.

Definitly NOT like many other Profs! Dr. Ganter is young, tough, knows what she is doing. She is German, probably therefore the 'ja?' ('right?') at the end of her sentences. Gives great examples from all over the world. Readings are very interesting and recent. 50% for the case study was too much. The study questions were helpful, TA not really.

50% case study, 30% midterm, 20% from tutorial & presentation in tutorial. -> Sarah rambles on a lot and sometimes is not clear on what she is trying to tell the class. -> delivery is poor -> Midterm is based on study questions she made. -> sometimes takes attendance in class

Very engaging lecturer and avoids repeating exactly what's in the readings so it makes lectures worth showing up to. Talks a lot about labour movements - personally I love that. As mentioned in other reviews he doesn't upload slides, which was a bit difficult, but assignments rely more on the readings than specific content of lectures.
Good lecturer, but you gotta be ready to take a ton of notes really quickly, as he doesn't post his slides, and there's a lot of them.

She doesn't allow electronic devices in her class, which I think it's good. But her lectures are too dry.I'm either falling in sleep or missing information from  her lecturing because my writing cannot follow her. A LOT of tasks in this course. enroll carefully

Ok prof. But the structure of her course needs some work. It dies not help us students, it's extremely rigid and she and her ta's don't take our busy schedules into account. Her teaching is good, nd interesting enough, but she really needs better ta's. The TA ruined this course for me.ruined it.
well dont know what to say

Vlad is an awesome guy, he is super nice and really passionate about the subject. The problem is he is hard to understand and goes off on random tangents which makes the class difficult to sit through. He really cares about the students and as much as I like him as a person, as a prof I would say I really didn't get anything out of the class
ride on vlad

Passionate teacher. Finals are based on Hesmondhalgh and assignment. TA class are important because it's worth huge percentage. Lecture class basically is from the textbook. Assignments are fun. Just focus on textbook and mainpoints on lectures

He is very interested in the material although at times is off topic. The assignments are easy TAs are great and he is really passionate about what he does. if you get past the boring lectures I think youll enjoy the class!

Easy going, friendly, prof and not too hard of a marker. But, lectures are completely useless. Just attend the tutorials and read the texts and you will be fine. BTW, there are no midterms and final is open-book.

I'll have to agree with prior ratings, Vlad really doesn't seem to grasp the subject material AT ALL, it was difficult to sit through an entire lecture. That being said, if you have good writing skills, you should find that good grades are easy to come by. He's also good about replying to e-mails, and working through any problems you may encounter.

Really nice person.  But his teaching methods are awful.  He doesn't seem to understand the material, thus his ability to teach it is rather limited.  He rants about unintelligible things and talks about Britney Spears a lot, TOO MUCH. Tutorials are useful to attend, lectures not so much...

He's a nice guy, seems really interested in the material, but most of the time I have no idea what he's murmuring about. His lecture notes are helpful and clear though, and the text isn't too hard to read, so if you study those for the tests, you'll be fine.

So appalled by the quality of her lecture that I am going out of my way to post this while still in class. I have no problem with professors choosing to use a variety of presentation tools, but a uni professor of COMMUNICATIONS shouldn't be using a large font on MS Word for "slides". Information is banal (even for a 200lv) and often inaccurate. Boo

She is a helpful prof. It is not hard to get a good grade in her course but you have to follow her instructions strictly in order not to lose marks. Her assignemnts are relatively easy. The first and the second papers are marked by the TAs, so it is easy to get a good mark. The last assignment is marked by the prof., so put more hard work on it lol
Dr. Nair is one of the best Profs I've ever had. She always looks out for your best interest and is willing to help you in anyway she can.
Meera is obsessed with copyright law and even makes one of the assignments based on it. But, she is very clear in her teaching and in her instructions for the assignments. Easy to get a good grade.

People give her a hard time, but she's actually quite personable and willing to help but you need to seek it from her if you need it. Assignments required some out-of-the-box thinking which people hated but I appreciated. She laid out the expectations for all assignments and the exam VERY clearly, if you followed them you got the grades- simple.

This class is not very interesting, although she does try to incorporate outside 'fun' things such as TEDtalks every couple classes. For me, though, this class was too heavily focused around copyright. And she gave us her own blog to read. Ugh.

Meera is the most approachable prof I've ever had. She is genuinely interested in the subject and willing to discuss present-day applications. She tries to mix up the material and have the class involved. A great prof and person, unfortunately, the curriculum does not highlight this in the best way.

She is extremely boring, but she does try really hard to make the class/material interesting. However, there is nothing I find interesting about that class and she is so focused on "copyright", I forget it's a "cultural industries" class. Plus the assignments are HORRIBLE.
She's alright... kind of boring but I think she knows it. She tries to keep material somewhat interesting but personally, topics are not very grabbing.
